@Nornor, yes, prototype is basically just declaring ahead of time for the compiler: "this will exist"
in the case you didn't match your actual definition to the forward declaration, the compiler errors out

Author: Midge#3751
Content:
@Hun I think this is a sufficient explanation for someone first starting:
`pass by value` means you only give the function a value (with a certain type, of course, e.g., Int)
`passing by reference` means giving the function the actual place in memory the argument is kept (see: pointer)

so `a` remains `10` not because of "curly braces", but because it was passed by value to `set_int`, thus when `set_int` ran, all it did was create a copy of `a` and changed said copy's value

Author: Midge#3751
Content: Those who are more guru than me may wish to correct/elaborate on my definitions but the problem I have with generally defining these terms is that the implementation per language can be pretty different, so it gets quite confusing. Luckily tho you're just thinking about C, and as far as I can remember in the coursework, what I hinted toward (a pointer being the key to pass by reference) is fine

Author: _Kios#8518
Content: @Hun  when using arrays and sending them as a parameter to a function, you are sending the actual array. To be more technical about it, a array will decay to a pointer so it's mandatory  when sending arrays to send it's length too.  When sending a single int value,  it will be sent as a copy to a function. So any change made in the function will not change the  behavior of the original value. If we did sent as in the following example void set_int(int& x) ->& meaning reference to a actual variable, then we would modified the mentioned variable

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `double numbers[10];`  will declare an array of 10 doubles and `numbers[9]` for example, will be the 10th element in that array.   `double *numbers = malloc (sizeof(double) * 10);`  will also give you space to hold 10 doubles, and again `numbers[9]` will be the 10th one.   In both of those cases, `*(numbers + 9)` will also give you the 10th element.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: this is because the compiler knows how much space each double takes, so adding 1 will add 1  sizeof(object) to the address.  Let's say that the address of `numbers` is 0x300.  then `numbers[1]` will have the address of 0x308  because a double takes 8 bytes of memory.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Let's say it's a char array instead.  Then `char letters[10];` would give you 10 chars' worth of space, and `char[1]` would be 1 byte farther along in memory, since chars have sizeof 1.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @muffinbreakfast ^^

Author: muffinbreakfast#5216
Content: @curiouskiwi if i declare a pointer and space like this double *numbers = malloc (sizeof(double) * 10);

Author: muffinbreakfast#5216
Content: can i access memory locations like this numbers[9] ? or do i HAVE to do this: *(numbers + 9) ?

Author: muffinbreakfast#5216
Content: im also wondering why would i ever declare it with malloc instead of declaring a simple array?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: "can i access memory locations like this numbers[9] ? "  Yes, as I said in my example.  the square bracket notation is just a shortcut syntax to the other one.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: as for why you'd use malloc?  it's for dynamic allocation, so if you don't know you need 10 numbers until you're running the program for instance, then you can malloc based on another variable.  Or, if you are requiring a lot of memory, it may be safer to use malloc since that uses a different part of memory (the heap) versus a locally declared array which uses the stack (which is smaller).   In your particular example, you most likely wouldn't use malloc.

Author: Natters#6581
Content:
I need help understanding WK2 filename scores2.c
This is the introduction of arrays, and `void chart(int score)` is written at the bottom of the code, but nowhere in the code is there an integer labeled `score`. How does C know to output scores 1, 2, & 3 from `int score`? Doesn't it have to be something like `int scores[]` in order for C to recognize there are multiple integers sharing the scores prefix?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you are calling the `chart` function in a loop, each time with an individual integer `scores[i]` as the argument:  `chart(scores[i])`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if your scores[3] has {10, 5, 7}, say, then it calls `chart(10)` then chart(5) then chart(7)

Author: Natters#6581
Content:
ok, i think i see how it recognizes the integer. I noticed the code locates any integer that contains the characters `score` in it.
If I change the chart function to `void chart(int scor)` or `void chart(int sco)` or `void chart(int s)` it'll still function properly

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it has nothing to do with the name

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you could say `void chart(int x)` and it would still work, as long as you referred to `x` in your definition of the function.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the variable name that the function uses for its arguments is not tied to the variable names of the values that are given to it.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: have you watched the Functions short yet?  I'd suggest that if this is at all confusing.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b7-0sb-DV84

Author: Natters#6581
Content:
oh! ok i see it now! The function is defined on line 21 `chart(scores[i]);`
and then line 26's `void chart(int score)` is used to define the value of score in line 29's  `for (int i = 0; i < score; i++)`

Author: Natters#6581
Content:
Line 21 is basically telling Line 26 that `int score = scores[i]` so this data can transfer to line 29.

Thank you @curiouskiwi

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content:
Here is some sample code from one of the cs50 beyond lectures (ORM and API) : 
```py
# >> In models.py
class Passenger(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = "passengers"
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String, nullable=False)
    flight_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey("flights.id"), nullable=False)

# >> In application.py
# Make instance of passenger class.
    passenger = Passenger(name=name, flight_id=flight_id)
```

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Anyone know why (when they create the class instance), they repeat the variables?  Aka `name = name` and `flight_id = flight_id`?

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Is it just for clarity?

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content:
It seems like this would also work?  
```py
# Make instance of passenger class.
    passenger = Passenger(name, flight_id)
```

Author: Wlerin#0016
Content: @Penderrin The variables aren't being repeated. The `name` and `flight_id` on the left hand side are the names of the keyword parameters (i.e. Columns) you are passing the right hand side variables into. If you look at the class definition of Passenger, there's a field before `name` and `flight_id`: `id`. If you tried to pass them in positionally like that, the program would try to assign your variable "name" to the column "id".

Author: Wlerin#0016
Content: If anything needs to change it would be using unique names for the right hand side variables to make clear to the reader that they aren't the same thing, but ultimately it doesn't make a difference to the program.

Author: Wlerin#0016
Content: ah it's SQLAlchemy

Author: Wlerin#0016
Content: <https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/tutorial.html#create-an-instance-of-the-mapped-class>

Author: 0x4E696E6A75#6171
Content:
in lecture 6 i didn't understand the difference between interpret and compile 
they both will go to 0 and 1 but interpret with more step that's all

Author: Usako Heika#6462
Content: I don't know if you still need help with that (and I hope I'm explaining it right now): If you interpret the stuff you wrote  your programm won't rly change. It will be interpreted every time you want to run it. So thats at least slower than running a compiled programm. A compiled programm will be compiled to machine code once (or more often if you have any bugs and decide to compile it again (that's the make blabla.c step) but if you compiled it you can run it as often as you want to without compiling it again (thats the ./blablabla argv step) and it won't be compiled again because your programm is already readable for your computer. So ofc it's much faster

Author: Usako Heika#6462
Content: even if compiling sounds better compiling has a big disadvantage: you have to compile it again and again and again for different kinds of machines, so if the user wants to download your problem it can be, that this isn't possible because you didn't compile the right version for him. Interpreted programms instead normally bring interpreters for different machines with them. There languages who use mixed versions of this stuff, too (f.e. java)

i have another question

of course C was faster and i know that but the question is why people use python for big data and it not slow so has the python have libraries for big data so fast ?! so you can't notice that the python is slow üòï

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: When people do big data in Python, they really do the big data in optimized C libraries, and direct them from Python. They essentially do the high-level stuff in a language that's more readable, while not sacrificing most of the performance.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: There's some performance loss every time you need to move data between Python and C, so you'd reduce those where possible.

Author: 0x4E696E6A75#6171
Content: @Blauelf  you mean they use python as Pseudocode for C ü§î

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: More like Python for manager and C for worker jobs. The C code is good in doing very simple tasks on large amounts of data.

Content: In my opinion, if you're writing ES6+ code, or transpiling to ES5.1 anyway, use `let` and `const` most of the time. Performance might be slightly worse for block-scope, not sure about that. Author: Nornor#4436
Content: Can someone plz explain how is the time complexity of Mege Sort *nlogn*, i understand the logn part because of diving by 2 logn times but y multiply that by n?

Author: Nornor#4436
Content:
i see it says because every number will move logn time but how so? Lets say we got the array "1234"
if we divide by 
2 we get "12" and "34"
then dividing again we'll get "1"  , "2" and "3", "4"
so to get "1" for example we divided logn times but to get 2 we just got back 1 step and divided once to get it

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: i hope my problem is clear

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
We have ceil(log2 n) levels of recursion. Each level, each of the array elements will be copied to another array. Maybe you count comparisons, but the O(n) of each level persists. There's no operation with a worse complexity.

And together this makes O(n log n).

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: oh so that is without comparisons?

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: also, sry but wdym by ceil(log2 n)

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You could also add number of comparisons and values copied. Still O(n). Any constant terms and constant factors disappear.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Ceil is short for "ceiling", means rounding up. Log2 here means logarithm to the base of 2.

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: i see now, thx a lot. It was rly confusing me for some reason

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: Honestly, pointers rly confused me and messed up all the knowledge i have (or that's what i thought ). So, i wanna revise with u guys some definitions and stuff.

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: First "int x;" means "hey give me space in the memory to store and int and name that space 'x' "

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: and if we do sth like " x = 0 " this means that the value inside the bytes in the memory is "0"

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: Second, "int *y;" means "hey give me some space in memory to store an address which points to an int value and name that space 'y' "

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: and "y = 0" in that context means that address is '0'

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: meanwhile if we do " *y = 0 " means that the int value which is pointed with the address is 0

Content: is all that right?

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: cuz if so, then doing equations with the variable "x" should be the same as doing equations with " *y" but not "y"

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: and if all that is right then all what "*" does in the context of pointers is literally "the pointing"

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: also what happens when i do "int *y = 0" is this zero the address or the value pointed to by the address

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671

Content: In your example, `int *y = 0;`  you are declaring an int pointer and setting its value to 0 (ie NULL)

Content: k so there is other stuff that's confusing me now

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: how is that

Author: Nornor#4436

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: to be clear the part confusing me in using [i] notation with pointers

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: according to some website i found it says that it's valid but other say u can't do that and that's only for arrays

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: square bracket notation is simply syntactic shorthand for using pointer arithmetic.  So if you have an array (say, a string, a char array that ends in null) called `name`, then `name[2]` is the same as `*(name + 2)`  (ie, add 2 to the address stored in name, and then dereference that address to give me access to the value there)

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: oh that's awesome

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: an array's variable "decays" to a pointer when needed, as it actually holds the address of the first element

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: ah i see

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: i rly love everything about this course, from its contents to the staff it's all awesome. ty very much

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so you'd really only use square bracket notation when you have an array, because it makes no sense otherwise. If you had an int pointer, what would it mean to say 'give me the memory 2 blocks farther along' since that's not memory that you need to know about.

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: oh i see

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and to be clear  `*(name + 2)`   the compiler knows how many bytes to move along based on the type of pointer.  so if you have `char *name`  then, chars are one byte each, so you'll get the address that is 2 bytes along.  If you had `int nums[5];` as an array, then `*(nums+2)` or `nums[2]` will give you the memory 8 bytes along, since the size of an integer is 4 bytes.  (or maybe 2 bytes or 8 bytes depending on what `sizeof(int)` is)

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: so that's why we have to specify the data type of the pointer when declaring it?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: there is such a thing as a void pointer, but you can't do any arithmetic on it

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: but what does it point to?

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: what can kind of data

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: they are generally used when you don't care what they point to.  You wouldn't really declare a void pointer on its own (you can, but it would be rare).  But they are used in function declarations as a way of saying "I can take any kind of pointer".    For example, there's a function called `memcpy` which copies memory from one spot to another.  It doesn't care what is in that memory.  It takes 2 void pointers (plus the size of the block) as arguments.  Any pointer type is compatible so you can actually pass it 2 int pointers or 2 char pointers or any types in order to copy memory.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
As we know the function `compare_strings` is returning `true`, we could add `== true`, but there is no need for that. If it's meant to return a boolean value, we can use it directly in a condition.
In C, boolean is not a built-in type. Instead, anything that's 0 is interpreted as false, and anythin non-zero is true. `true` is just one somewhat arbitrary non-zero value, and many functions even specify to return a value of zero or non-zero, not referring to `true` at all.
I could iterate strings, like
```c
    char *str = "Hello";
    for (int i = 0; str[i]; i++) // loop will stop at null terminator '\0'
        putchar(str[i]);
    putchar('\n');
```
I could iterate linked lists (you will meet them in week 4, I guess)
```c
    for (node *cursor = root; cursor; cursor = cursor->next) // loop will stop at NULL pointer
        printf("%i\n", cursor->data);
```
In all those cases, the condition is tested for being non-zero, doesn't require the condition to be `true`. It's often more readable to add a `!= '\0'`, or `!= NULL`, or `!= 0`. All those three would not add any bytecode, as equality is tested by subtracting both sides and see whether the result is zero, and here we can optimize away the subtraction of zero.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Mildred Any name can resolve to another IP address. Having www and the version without subdomain point to the same web server is a convention just for dealing with people too dumb for typing it right.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: For example, we have a subdomain pointing to some marketing agency who do marketing mailings and use the domain name with their own server for tracking links.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Having different domains on same IP actually makes it hard to use HTTPS üò¶

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: So, for example, what's the difference between developers.facebook.com and facebook.com/developers.html. Aren't they both a partition in the same server

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Not necessarily. By the way, those domain names resolve to different IP addresses in different areas of the world, because they try to send you to a server close to you. And then you get one of the local IP addresses, and your neighbour might get another (round-robin). Also, there are load balancers, so the content served by that IP address might be from one of thousands of servers.

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: I see

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: So, I think have a better understanding now, let's say I bought the domain name example.com. And I have 2 servers for example. I can name one of them www.example.com and the other developer.example.com is that right?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Sure. Those are separate DNS records.

Author: Nornor#4436
Content: Awesome.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
You can even have both be served by the same server, with the same IP address, the browser will tell the serving IP address which server name's content it requests.
It gets funny when you switch to HTTPS. First, an encrypted channel is established, then the server name is sent. But if the server manages multiple names, it will have to provide certificates for all of them, as it does not yet know which one the client will request. There is SNI (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_Name_Indication), but that means somebody reading your packets knows which server name you want to connect to.

@Berky_Ross It's sort of an invitation for the user to enter the data. Functions get_int(), get_string() etc have it, so "get_positive" is made more or less similar to them, for uniformity.
So now a user running the program will get "Positive integer: " and cursor to enter that integer. But there could be another text there, for example, " i = get_positive_int("Your age: ");". Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the function `compare` returns either true or false.  so that gets sent back to the calling function and you end up with `if (true)`  if it was true   or `if (false)`  if it was false.  So there's no need to to say `if (true == true)`  or `if (false == true)` since you've already got a true or false.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you didn't have to say `if (islower(s[i]) == true)`  because it would evaluate to true or false based on the return value of islower (in this case 0 if false and non-0 if true)

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content: Sort of. It calculates the value of the expression in the parentheses after "if" and then sees if if it true or false (in fact it can also interpret a non-zero number as true and 0 as false, but that possibility does not make programs more readable, lol, so down with it). Comparison operators are one of many possible ways to get a boolean value that can be used as a condition.

Content: Can you elaborate on what you mean by it copies byte for byte please?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Reads a byte, writes the byte.
There's an interesting thing with that loop. `fgetc` returns the character cast to `unsigned char`, or `EOF`. The assignment to `ch` will automatically convert it to `char` (which for us is `signed char`). But the assignment expression evaluates to the assigned value without the implicit typecast.

Author: Jammar#8645
Content:
Hey all. I'm on lecture 3. 

So a char* doesn't actually know where that string ends, it just gives the address of that first char. But then, when David compares char *s and char *t, how do they come out being "same".... it's because his compare char-by-char for-loop also consists of the strlen condition, right?

So there always has to be something that checks where the string ends, otherwise a char * will point to an address, and whatever comes after that, infinitely? So let's say a have a big program and I accidently point to a memory early in the code without it stopping, it will regard all of the follow memory/code to that char*?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the end of a string is indicated by the presence of a null char.  string-related functions will use that null char.  `strlen` for example, starts counting the chars from the beginning of the string (where the pointer is pointing) until it hits a null.  At that point, it knows it has reached the end and stops counting.

Author: Jammar#8645
Content: Right yeah. So any function I use for strings ‚Äì or any time I use a char * ‚Äì that other function will know to make use of the null char.

Author: Jammar#8645
Content: So let's say I tried to printf char *a.  Unless the printf function knows when to stop (as in finding the \0), it would print forever

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it will print until it finds the null, which may coincidentally be right where you need it, or you might get some garbage bytes printed first

Author: Jammar#8645
Content: Think I get it, thanks @curiouskiwi .

Author: Banan#2842
Content:
@Jesse 

1. Pretty sure i solved the first problem by doing ```pip (or pip3) install psycopg2-binary``` after installing setuptools and six
2. Make sure you've run ```export DATABASE_URL=(your key)``` (this will reset on terminal quit)
3. In your py file, use ```os.getenv("DATABASE_URL")``` instead of checking your key itself
4. You might want to have ```from tempfile import mkdtemp
app.config["SESSION_FILE_DIR"] = mkdtemp()``` in your file to create a temporary directory to store user sessions in. Might not be totally necessary, but i saw Brian Yu do it in his CS50 Beyond lectures.

Oh yeah and i should've prefaced this by saying that I have only gone through the CS50 beyond lectures, and not the full course, so take whatever i say with a pound or two of salt.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `get_positive_int("Positive integer: ")`   this calls the `get_positive_int` function and passes it the string `"Positive integer: "` to be used as the prompt.  Note that the argument to the function is `string prompt` meaning, it takes in a string calling it `prompt` and then uses `prompt` in the call to `get_int`

Content: While using them in printf, they have no difference at all, but when you use with scanf, they're a bit different, where %d takes integer value as signed decimal integer and %i takes integer value as integer value with decimal, hexadecimal or octal type. @Carixo

Author: Don Draper#8540
Content: For lecture 3 on memory, in the example for getting 2 strings and comparing them to see if they're the same or different, are we assuming that if an "if ()" contains a caller function within the parentheses that returns a bool, the "if()" function will only execute if the bool returns as true? Is this generally true for "bool" being used in this way? And bool is only a CS50 function right?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Do you have a link and timestamp within the video for what you mean?
`bool` is defined in `stdbool.h`, which is a standard library included in `cs50.h` (so we get it indirectly). C has no native boolean types, it usually differentiates between zero and non-zero. `false` is `0`, and `true` is `1`, but some functions usually treated as returning a boolean value (formally returning an `int`) return various non-zero values (which might provide additional information). For example, you could use `if (strcmp(str1, str2)) { printf("Different!\n"); }`, ignoring that it actually returns a positive or negative value telling you the lexicographic order.

Author: Don Draper#8540
Content:
I don't, but it was toward the beginning of the lecture when we discussed how strcmp() works. 

That makes sense now. Thank you

Author: Fungo#4832
Content:
I'm a a bit (heh) confused about something.

So if a binary table looks something like this:

128 | 64 | 32 | 16 | 8 | 4 | 2 | 1

The largest number you can derive from here is 255, correct?

So, why do they say the largest integer you can derive from 32 bits is 4294967296?

If you drew that binary table above all the way out to 32 bits, the *last number* would be 4294967296, but if you gave each one of these bits a value of `1`, wouldn't it come out to be way more than 4294967296?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: An unsigned 32-bit integer can hold numbers from 0 to 4.294.967.295, that's 4.294.967.296 different values.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: If I gave each bit a value of 1, I could count from 0 to 32.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: 33 different values.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Or do you mean if all bits are set to 1 (with their value being a power of 2)? Well, that's 2^32-1, or 4.294.967.295.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: 2^32 in the sense of power, not C's `^` bitwise XOR operator.

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: But each of those bits represents a larger number, correct? So in my example. if you gave each bit a value of 1, you would add them all up to be 255

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: So couldn't you do the same with 32 bits

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: So you would start adding up with the value of 4294967296

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I don't understand what you are saying. In an unsigned integer of 32 bit, the bits have values from 2^0=1 to 2^31=2.147.483.648. All of those sum up to 4.294.967.295.

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: Okay I totally messed up

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: Look at this javascript function I wrote to figure that out

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: Notice I put 32 instead of 31

Author: Fungo#4832
Fungo#4832
Content: Wait that was the fixed version

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: Basically, I had 32 and it was giving me a much larger n#

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You probably want to start at 2^0, not 2^1.

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: You would be correct

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: easier to read

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: So `for (let n = 0; n < 32; n++)`

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: This is actually a relief. I was concerned at the fact I didn't seem to be grasping this, but now I see my mistake

Author: Fungo#4832
Content: Thought it was going to be a larger problem/miscomprehension

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: There's a sum formula for those geometric series, and for binary it boils down to 2^(number of bits)-1.

Content:
Hello, in #include  <stdio.h> what "h" and ''.' stands for?

Also we have been told that <stdio.h> is default C' s library. If C again requires a library to be used, what is C itself? Just the way it tells the computer sequence of 0 and 1? But it is stupid

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: C is just a language like English but one that can be translated to something the computer understands more easily

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: .h is the extension for a header file

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: It's where all the prototypes for functions are

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The prototypes for functions you might want to expose at least. If the header is to be included by something else, don't add implementation details that are subject to change.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Like if you provide a sort function, and you implement merge sort having a separate merge function, I would not add its signature to the header. The caller does not need to know, and I might later decide to change the implementation.

Author: Don Draper#8540
Content: For the lecture on data structures, when David mentioned that realloc() will return a new pointer to a new chunk of memory that houses the original size + an increase in size, he also said the total memory used is equal to all the arrays added up. But when he ran valgrind on the program without freeing the memory, valgrind showed a leak of 12 B of memory which represents 3 integers worth of memory leaked. Shouldn't valgrind show 12 B + 6 B + 3 B = 21 B from the previous chunks of memory that aren't being used anymore?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
@Fungo  > Are all chars the same size? 
Yes, a char is one byte.  A string will require storage equal to the number of chars plus the NUL char, so a string like "foobar" will required 7 bytes of memory.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: But the variable itself (the `string` variable, which is actually a char pointer) will require its own memory and in our IDE, that's an 8 byte (64 bit) value.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Don Draper `realloc` takes care of releasing any memory it is no longer using, so valgrind won't report it as a leak.

Content: @hi im steven The `string` type variable is a pointer, lives on your stack. The `"aa"` string literal is stored in a read-only area of your programme, neither on stack nor heap.

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: @curiouskiwi  Uh oh, that's no good if we assign a pointer to point at an area away from the malloced area without freeing it. Anyway to free it after that? Anytime we do something like ```"this is a string literal"``` or ```"so is this"``` these strings get saved in read only memory?

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: Is this correct?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you can't free it after you've lost the pointer

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and yes, those are string literals which the compiler knows cannot change so they are stored with the program itself and are immutable.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: remember a `char *` is just a pointer.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it has no memory of its own

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it holds an address

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when you say `char *name = "joe";`  you create a pointer that is pointing to memory where "joe" is stored (and that memory is read-only stored with the program)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when you say `char *name = malloc(10);`  you create a pointer that is pointing at a block of memory at the address that malloc gave you.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you could then say, `name[0] = 'j';  name[1] = 'o';  name[2] = 'e'; name[3] = '\0';`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or you could use `strcpy(name, "joe");`  which would do the same thing

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you would have done all this in speller üòâ  with your hashtable.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Any non-object property value gets copied over, any object gets copied as a deep copy itself (using just the enumerable properties), recursively. So `o.obj` and `o3.obj` are different things.
With that code, `deepCopy(null)` might be surprising. Also no checks for circular references (like `obj = {}; obj.o = obj; console.log(deepCopy(obj));`).

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: Hello, in lecture 4, when we write data into a node, which is essentially just a custom struct, David is using this syntax:

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: However, previously we used '.' to define a struct field, so why don't we use it here? Something like "n.number = number;"?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `n->number` is equivalent to `(*n).number`, i.e. it gets the member called `number` from the struct that `n` points to.

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: Hello Kiwi, yeah i got that its just a pointer to a node , but what is the node name in this case? isn't it "n" ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `node *n = malloc(sizeof(node));`   `n` is a pointer to a node

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: So if i declared it as "node n;" it would get space allocated in stack instead, and i could use "n.number = number" in that case?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes, but you'd only have one.  how would you do a linked list?

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: it's just an example for clarification

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: ty

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: sure. you can certainly declare `node mynode;`  and then set `mynode.number = 5;`  for example.

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: I think i got confused by the similar case where we used pointer as an array

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: what's that from? it shouldn't work, because x[10] is outside the memory that was allocated.

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: Yeah that was the point of this example shown at lectures.

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: I only meant that for arrays we can use poiner to which malloc assigns an address as a name of an array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes, because `x[10]` is a shorthand for `*(x + 10)`

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: So if we are not dealing with an array, we can either name a variable (or struct) and it gets autoassigned space in stack, or store that via malloc(), but in that case variable stays nameless?

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: can we name a node and store it via malloc() ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: malloc always returns an address (which means you store it in a pointer)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you are using the stack, then `int number = 5;`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you are using the heap, then `int *number = malloc(sizeof(int) * 1);  *number = 5;`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you wouldn't use malloc unless you needed to dynamically allocate the memory (or you expect to use more memory than might be available in your stack)

Author: d1m0n#4393
Content: thank you

Author: Nyao#5540
Content:
I don't wanna say just skip the pset unless you're sure you understand everything.
Part of programming is being able to look at the documentation of an API or a library and be able to use that information in your own program.  So it is good practice for real life situations.  For example, just because you know JS or Python doesn't mean you can write a Discord bot. You still need to go look through their API
That being said if you're feeling really frustrated, try working on Recover instead.  And try boiling your questions down to single issues you can tackle.  You can do it!  Even if it is frustrating.

Author: Mo#8697
Content:
Hi, everyone.
Have a couple of questions on this recursion example from short videos.
1) As I understand collatz(n/2) is a function, and it will be dividing by two until number will turn into 1?
2) In case when number odd number turns into even, how does program returns on previous lines without a loop?
3) Why is 1 added to collatz(n) for recursion cases?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
The collatz function returns the number of steps to get to 1.  

So the base case is if you call `collatz(1)` then there are 0 steps (since you are already at 1).

If the number if even, then you add a step and then call collatz on (n/2).

If the number is odd, then you add a step and then call collatz on (3n + 1)

Let's say you call `collatz(12)`    The sequence is

`12 -> 6 -> 3 -> 10 -> 5 -> 16 -> 8 -> 4 -> 2 -> 1`

which is 9 steps.

Author: Mo#8697
Content:
Yeah, I understood how sequence works, just do not get it specifically in this code

So function 'collatz' just calculates amount of steps, right? Like collatz (5) = 5, collatz (7) = 16
Why in code we write instructions for odd/even numbers in brackets (collatz(n/2) and collatz(3*n+1)), if function 'collatz' does know what to do anyway?

Author: Mo#8697
Content: And why do we ad '1' so amount of steps that 'collatz' made in order to get to 1?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it's recursive, so you are calling the collatz function, and to call a function, you use the function name and then parenthesis, just like other functions in C.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and you have to add 1 to actually count the step

Author: Mo#8697
Content: I am sorry, I don't get it. Why in code we can't just write collatz (n)?

Author: Mo#8697
Content: It will calculate steps, and you do not need two write two recursive conditions, makes code simpler as well

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: what would you expect to happen if you called `collatz(n)`?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: how will it calculate the steps?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
so I put some print statements in the collatz function and then called it with 12.  ```Enter n: 12
12 is even: 12/2 = 6    ... calling collatz(6)
6 is even: 6/2 = 3      ... calling collatz(3)
3 is odd: 3*3+1 = 10    ... calling collatz(10)
10 is even: 10/2 = 5    ... calling collatz(5)
5 is odd: 3*5+1 = 16    ... calling collatz(16)
16 is even: 16/2 = 8    ... calling collatz(8)
8 is even: 8/2 = 4      ... calling collatz(4)
4 is even: 4/2 = 2      ... calling collatz(2)
2 is even: 2/2 = 1      ... calling collatz(1)
is 9 steps```

Author: Mo#8697
Content: Alright, then this code loops. How does this code continue to loop, if we did not provide condition to loop?

Author: Mo#8697
Content: or is it loops because of 'return 1'?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it is calling itself.  a function ends with a return statement.  So you call collatz(12) in main,  then collatz make a copy of itself and call collatz(6)  and then that makes a copy and calls collatz(3) etc etc ... until it finally gets to the collatz(1) which returns 0 and then it will "unwind" and return each value until it finally gets all the way back to main.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I'd suggest looking at this example: http://www.pythontutor.com/visualize.html#code=%23include%20%3Cstdio.h%3E%0A%0Aint%20collatz%28int%20n%29%0A%7B%0A%20%20%20%20if%20%28n%20%3D%3D%201%29%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20return%200%3B%0A%20%20%20%20if%20%28n%20%25%202%20%3D%3D%200%29%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20return%201%20%2B%20collatz%28n%20/%202%29%3B%20%0A%20%20%20%20else%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20return%201%20%2B%20collatz%283%20*%20n%20%2B%201%29%3B%0A%7D%0Aint%20main%28void%29%20%7B%0A%20%20%0A%20%20int%20num%20%3D%205%3B%0A%20%20printf%28%22steps%3A%20%25i%5Cn%22,%20collatz%28num%29%29%3B%0A%7D&cumulative=false&curInstr=0&heapPrimitives=false&mode=display&origin=opt-frontend.js&py=c&rawInputLstJSON=%5B%5D&textReferences=false

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: (wow, that's a long URL) ... anyway, step through the code and see how it puts the function on the stack over and over as it calls itself and then 'rewinds' to return each value.

Author: Mo#8697
Content:
Okay, so return 1 makes this function call itself again and 'loop', until n==1.

Could you explain why in recursive cases we sum '1' and 'collatz'?

Author: Mo#8697
Content: I understand how function makes steps. But I do not get how does it count it

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the 1 is counting the steps because everytime you return from the function, you are adding 1 to the return value.  so at the end, it's the number of times you called collatz on an `n` value other than 1.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Let's use a simpler example of `n` = 4.

Author: Mo#8697
Content:
Okay, got it, thank you. I guess I will read more on 'return' function.
When I was working with 'Caesar', I assumed it only does stop program when 'Return 1' is being executed. However, somehow return 0 was stopping program from further execution as well. Moreover, I did not know that 'Return' function is doing additional count.

Author: Mo#8697
Content: So from what I see now, '1' is not just command to stop program, it is actual result of function as well.

Author: Mo#8697
Content: @curiouskiwi , in example you gave, when all these '1' returned, are they stored somewhere? Can't see in debug, just see that function reduces n until it will be 1, therefore, function returns 0, and moves on to next function to print sum of 1, that were returned before.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5631447/how-recursion-works-in-c

Author: Mo#8697
Content: Hi, Kiwi. Nice information on this link! I also read some of your replies on recursion in plurality, and it all made a bit more sense now. Function calls itself withing itself.

Author: Mo#8697
Content: Thank you for your help

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: Hi, while watching the `dynamic memory allocation` short, I am having a bit of a struggle understanding what these arrays actually mean. I don't think I've encountered it in the notes and it is leaving a bit of a gap.

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: why the last 2 examples? what is the TA actually trying to depict?

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: and why use `array`?

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: `GetInt()` is trying to get an `int` not an array, am i wrong?

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: Sure, I understand that the TA is trying to show the difference between `stack` and `heap` by using `malloc()` but I just don't get the user of `array` and `float`....and specially the part `x* sizeof(float)`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: He's illustrating that an array is simply a contiguous bit of memory that is big enough to hold all of the elements.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if declared on the stack, the compiler will set aside as much memory to hold `x` number of floats.   And if you declare it on the heap, then you need `x` * the size of a float to store that

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: @curiouskiwi thank you. but what's with the transition from `int` to `float`? am I missing something?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the int was asking the user for the number of elements (ie `x`)

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: there isnt a transition

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: x is an int that shows the number of floats the array will hold

Author: jasonlee#1523
Content: ohh i see

Content: thanks guys

Author: fz72eaman#5560
Content: Hey everyon !!!,I was having a doubt, when a computer receives a certain alphabet does it always need to take up a byte of storage for an alphabet or can it  do away with just the right number of bits that can satisfactorily store the alphabet?

Author: „ÄéSixthSense„Äè#6565
Content: Specifically, it depends on the cpu.  In most machines today, the smallest addressable unit of memory is one byte. And some cpu are optimized for accessing a byte. And yeah, accessing a bit is slower. So a computer usually will take up a byte although it may sufficie to just use the exact number of bits needed. To answer your question, it doesn't always need to take up a byte.

Content: 0.1 in binary doesn't terminate - the computer can't store floats to infinite precision, and so it approximates what the actual value is. Floats are notorious for lack of precision, and that's why.

Author: Amine#2111
Content: in week 3 , i dont get the difference between the O and omega

Author: Amine#2111
Content: i guess it's just the same thing ?

Author: Anya L#2162
Content: @Amine No, it's not. As far as I understand, Big O is the rough number of steps a program takes to e.g. search for a piece of data if it's *the furthest away* from where we start searching. Omega is the same if the data is at *the nearest spot* possible from where we start searching. That's why for linear search Big O is n - we have to go through all elements and the last one is what we look for; and Omega is 1 - best case scenario - the first element is what we look for. The lecture and shorts do a pretty good job explaining it, but there's plenty more info online if you want to dive deeper

Author: Anya L#2162
Content: (I've grossly oversimplified the explanation, you really should just rewatch the course materials)

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Hi again @curiouskiwi . Whenever you have a moment could you let me know if I understood it correctly? This is on the topic of memory, imprecision and overflow. My take on yesterday's question follows bellow:

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content:
(a) A float has a limited number of bits where a value can be stored. Out of the 32 bits, 9 are occupied by the sign and the exponent. 

(b) That leaves me with 23 bits for the actual result. 

(c) 1 divided by 10 is just like 10 divided by 3‚Ää-‚Ääboth imperfect, but the later is just more immediately explicit with the result being 3.3333‚Ä¶ whereas in the former it takes about 9 decimal houses to spot the imperfection 0.10000000149‚Ä¶ 

(d) In the case of 1 divided by 10, the float has 23 bits available to store the result. This means that its able to store up to 27 decimal houses of that particular number. From then on it no longer has enough bits to store the number. This means the result is rounded to its nearest storable number. 

(e) From that point forward the computer just returns zeros. These zeros are not stored in the float itself and are rather just an expression of [null]. 

(f) That's what overflow is: the float's lack of memory to store the result in its infinite precision.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
We have 64 bits in a pointer for 2^64 different memory addresses.
If we group four of them to one hexadecimal digit, we have 16^16 memory addresses.
Still the same value, just a different notation.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: And this grouping has no influence on what the value actually means (bytes on this architecture)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: in other words, each *byte* has its own address, no matter what number notation we use to label that address.

Author: kellynsq#5335
Content: Probably missing something glaring here re the mario/???? example in Lecture 1. Why is it `while (n < 1)` rather than `while (n > 1)`? I thought the point is to get a positive integer n

Author: Marx#9510
Content: Well the answer is quite simple but counter-intuitive at first

Author: Marx#9510
Content: The reason why it's while n is *less than* 1, is because you're asking "do" to keep executing over and over and over again until the user inputs an int whose width is larger than 1. Therefore, the loop shall keep executing if the user inputs a value *lower* than 1.

Author: Marx#9510
Content: Does this make sense?

Author: Marx#9510
Content: and using cs50.h's help, get_int will also make it so that if the user inputs letters, words, etc, it will also ask again and again until the assigned value is correct

Author: Marx#9510
Content: So, like, if you do what you said and make it so that the value of n has to be greater than 1, whenever you input a value higher than 1, "do" will keep executing *while* the value is higher than what is specified

Author: Marx#9510
Content: I hope this helped, did I confuse you? :¬∑(

Author: kellynsq#5335
Content: Ah ok. I get it

Author: kellynsq#5335
Content: Thank you!

Author: Marx#9510
Content: No problem, but are you sure? It's better to keep asking until you get it, because misunderstanding something basic will lead to huge problems later on

Author: Dizson#2350
Content: I have two questions why do we use int main(void)? I know main is just a name we give to the integer, but why do we always use void? can we use others. Second questions is why do we use % in printf. is it for space and c1, c2, c3 in white is just to print those value. pic included

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: @Dizson main is the name of the function. C expects a main function to be present when compiling and that's the function that's called on running your program

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You'll learn about others that you can use in place of void later

Author: Dizson#2350
Content: ah thanks and why is it %c instead of just c?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: %c means a character will replace that

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: So c1 replaces the first %c, c2 replaces the second, etc

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Similarly %i and %d are used for integers

Author: Dizson#2350
Content: thank you so much

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You can use %i for characters, too, as they are 8-bit signed integers, ranging from -128 to 127. %i would show their ASCII value.

Content: It's a less efficient one, in the best case doing twice the comparisons necessary, but yes, looks like a bubble sort. Not that efficiency would be a strength of bubble sort.

Author: kzidane#6459
Content: Hi @ioan calin ! Using an SSH key should work. If you're facing an issue with that please let us know. Alternatively, you could either push to  directly to a branch with the same name as the identifier that comes after `submit50` in the problem specification (e.g., `cs50/problems/2020/x/hello`) or use GitHub's UI to upload to a branch with that name in your me50/USERNAME repo where USERNAME is your GitHub username. Or you could create a zip out of your submission and upload it at https://submit.cs50.io/upload/IDENTIFIER where IDENTIFIER is the problem identifier (e.g., `cs50/problems/2020/x/hello`). Yet another solution, if you're too concerned about using the password for your main GitHub account, is to create a separate GitHub account with a different password and use that instead.

Author: Marx#9510
Content: @tony thot aka scotty mcthotty The point of a global constant is if, for example for Week 3, you make a program related to voting, you wanna set the max number of available votes, and make that not change for the rest of the program, since otherwise it would be very exploitable

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: @Marx Any why can't you do that by declaring the max number of votes as a constant in a more local scope?

Author: Marx#9510
Content:
Well, it's just in case kept in a place where it will be easily accessible, so it won't require looking through all your code. On top of this, having it globally will make sure you don't accidentally try changing it in the future, like making it
```C
int const maxNumber = 9
maxNumber++;```

or something like that

Author: Marx#9510
Content: of course you wouldn't make a mistake like this, since they are right next to each other, but in thousands of lines, a mistake is bound to pop up

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
in #plurality  it's not a const int, global or otherwise.  It's ```// Max number of candidates
#define MAX 9
```

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: @marxplank but that mistake would be easily identified by the compiler wouldn't it? And I don't really get it, people turn variables into globals for quick access? Like "favorites" or quick access in windows explorer lol?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You should never use a global for "quick access".  A global is appropriate if you need it to be in scope in multiple functions.

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: Isn't that what marx is implying though? And that's definitely what I believe David said in that timestamp i linked

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I'm not sure where @Marx  got that idea. üôÇ

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: https://youtu.be/8PrOp9t0PyQ?t=3217

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: here it is again

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: oh, so that's specifically talking about constants.

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: ya global constants

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: but he then later moves the same variable to be a local variable in main

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: and states that its handy to keep the constant in global so when you come back to the program you can change it again so you don't have to sift through code.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes, so quite a specific situation

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but quite commonly, you might use a #define instead

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: but he doesnt use it like a global constant at all, he just made it global for convenience.

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: which sounds like bad practice to me

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: It's not bad practice.  As he said, it's just a convention that C programmers use and only in the case of constants.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and different folks have different styles.

Author: tony thot aka scotty mcthotty#2976
Content: Ok thank you

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Some algorithms are easier to understand when written in recursion. Not always as efficient.
Programming language Haskell actually does almost everything with recursion. Loops are a recursive function, and so on.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: If you like bubble sort, check out shaker sort, a bubble sort that changes direction all the time. Combine that with remembering the last swap, and you get better results with partially ordered arrays.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Of course, if you want to really sort, most times it's something like quicksort or mergesort.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: merge sort has the benefit of being stable, a quality quicksort lacks.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: In their JavaScript array sorting, Firefox used to have a non-stable algorithm. The ECMAScript standard (which JS is based on) does not guarantee stability. But it's industry standard, so they implemented a merge sort.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @curiouskiwi Those are great üôÇ

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: üòÇüòÇüòÇ amazing

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Or like the algorithm of it.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: I usually learn these algorithms to try my best to apply what's in mind to the code.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
In real life, if you know you don't need stable sorting, you use a library function. If you need stable sorting, you look more closely, and still use a library function.
But it's nice to understand how they work. And maybe you need to sort something that somehow is ill-fitted for library functions. And many sorting algorithms can teach you about recursion, about stacks, all those things.

Author: Berky_Ross#6951
Content: Ye, thnx for your answer, I'm learning a lot from you <3.

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: @Blauelf quicksort can be made stable pretty easily

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Easiest implementation requires more space though

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: If it's so easy, why is it not common?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Space requirement is the bad part of merge sort, and yes, for that there are also in-place versions that don't need as much extra space. They suck in other ways.

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You trade either space or time for stability in quicksort

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: So generally you'll have separate sorts available to you depending on whether you need stability or not

Author: kkkttt#3254
Content: In lecture4 professor says that we need to free the memory every time we finish using malloc. But I am confused when I try to do this for the functions other than main(): If I free them at last, I cannot return anything created by malloc, otherwise I could have created a memory leak..  How to fix this..

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
It's just important to `free` as soon as you don't need that memory any more, and most importantly *exactly* once. Often there are complementary functions, like `fopen` contains a `malloc`, while `fclose` frees that exact memory. In most cases where there isn't, you are usually meant to provide the memory to be written to, in the rare cases where a function returns allocated memory, it should mention that in the description.
For our `get_string` function, `free` will be invoked just before the programme ends, so we are essentially getting a memory leak that won't be reported, but you wouldn't ask for that many things anyway.

Author: kkkttt#3254
kkkttt#3254
Content: and for the `get_string` I have used valgrind to check it, but it says ``no leaks are possible``. May I know where can I find the source code for cs50.h? I can't find that on the manual page..

Author: drail159#6376
Content: https://github.com/cs50/libcs50/blob/develop/src/cs50.c

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: @kkkttt get_string won't give you a memory leak because it frees the memory before the program ends

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Blauelf means to say that since you're 'wasting' memory till then, it's like a memory leak

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
That kind of memory is returned to the operating system anyway when your programme quits, so keeping the memory allocated until the last second could be seen as masking a memory leak. The memory doesn't become unreachable, it's just blocked.
JavaScript itself cannot have the classic memory leak because it has automatic memory management ("garbage collection"), but you can definitely keep data in scope so it cannot be garbage collected. You can define functions anywhere in the code, and they have access to all the scopes outside, no simple resetting stack as in C, this causes a large number of variables to stay "accessible" and prevent them from garbage collection. It gets even more fun when adding DOM manipulation. A typical countermeasure would be to set the value of object-referencing variables to `null` or `undefined`once you no longer need them, greatly reducing the problem in many cases.

Author: shubham#5498
calcium#1779
Blauelf#6622
Content: @calcium The number of bytes does not differ, whether you have 1,3 (1 byte chunks, 3 chunks) or 3,1 (3 byte chunks, 1 chunk), it will always attempt to read the product of the two numbers in bytes. The difference is what it returns, as that's the number of successfully read chunks.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: And `sizeof(char)` is per definitionem `1`, you could use that to make that more explicit to the reader of the code.

Author: calcium#1779
Content:
thanks for the reply. when the read product (either 1,3 (1 byte chunks, 3 chunks) or 3,1 (3 byte chunks, 1 chunk)) are to be stored in the array "unsigned char bytes[3]", how does it know which product goes into which element of the array? 
I thought the size_t nmemb of fread will match with the ith element of array, where ith of nmeb goes into ith of the element within the array

Author: calcium#1779
Content:
btw, so basically for the fread,   
the size_t fread(void *ptr, size_t size, size_t nmemb, FILE *stream)
the size_t size and size_t nmemb are interchangeable

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
`fread` simply reads a stream of bytes, and stores them at the specified location, one byte after the other. Should work for the standard types, as those arrays store all the values contiguously.
This can cause issues if you have data structures that contain memory padding, where the compiler added unused bytes to have more efficient memory access.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `bmp.h` in `filter` declares various `struct`s in a way that the compiler won't add those padding bytes.

Author: samnull#2340
Content:
Lec 05: It's unclear to me what realloc does exactly, does it copy the array into a  new array or just extends the memory chunk of the old array?
Shouldn't  list be freed before line 26 if it copies into a new array as I understood ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: realloc will attempt to allocate the new space after the existing.  but if it isn't available , it will allocate an entirely new block and move everything there

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so realloc will return the same pointer if it didn't have to move it, or a new pointer address if it did

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
samnull#2340
Content: So if realloc didn't find enough space, does it move the old data to  a new space with enough memory or does it make a copy of the old data and then add the new data?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it copies it over

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
The reallocation is done by either:

a) expanding or contracting the existing area pointed to by ptr, if possible. The contents of the area remain unchanged up to the lesser of the new and old sizes. If the area is expanded, the contents of the new part of the array are undefined.
b) allocating a new memory block of size new_size bytes, copying memory area with size equal the lesser of the new and the old sizes, and freeing the old block.

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: on the ide, it generally extends the memory even for pretty large allocations

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: more info here: https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/memory/realloc

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: oh okay, sure thing.  Yes, the CS50 AP course runs on a high-school calendar, so it began in Sep 2019 (and, as such, it uses the CS50x2019 course filmed in 2018, since the 2019 course hadn't happened yet).

Content: Got it. Despite having the different lecture videos and different "shorts", They both link to the same .edu address and the same problem sets which is where the confusing crossover happened

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ah yes, that is confusing.   The AP course ends on 30 April anyway, so the majority of students in that course have been working on it since September (as part of their high school curriculum)

Author: Secato#5344
Content:
Hey Everyone
I just finished the lecture 4 (memory) and it was awesome to understand concepts like Heap, pointers and what bracket notation does under the hood.

A doubt popped up
1 - Whenever we create an array it is allocated sequentially in memory?
2 - If so, how languages with dynamic arrays deal with it since you don't know the size of the array beforehand?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Arrays are sequential in memory, which is why square bracket notation works

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You can realloc memory if you realise you've grown beyond the allocated size

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: (This is what get_string() does, it reads a string character by character, growing the memory as required)

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Hello üôÇ just a question. When we saw ```typedef struct node { int number; struct node *next; } node;``` and we next do ```node *n = malloc(sizeof(node));```   how is only 1 location in memory is being pointed for next? It feels like it's similar to a recursion and will continue to request for memory space.

Author: Yama#6436
Content: This question is related to week 5 lecture ^-^

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Pointers don't request memory, they're just another variable

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: They're generally just 8 bytes

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You'll have to do n->next = malloc(...)

Author: Yama#6436
Content: @Sanath In other words, the `struct node *next` is just saying this will be of type `struct node` whenever this variable will be created. And once it's created, if we don't assign anything it'll be 0/NULL?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: It's just a normal pointer

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: For your example, since n is pointing to a block allocd by malloc, n->next contains garbage values by default

Author: Yama#6436
Content: So similar to when we created an array. Where once it's created with s, s is just a pointer to where the array starts in memory and the s[0], s[1] are locations. But in regards to a linked list, n points to where the block (struck) is located and next to it would be similar to how an array is where n.number tells us where in memory this number is located in then n.next where the next pointing node is located in

Author: Yama#6436
Content: When you mention garbage values. What would that be? Like for example in Python/JavaSCript if we don't assign something it would be either undefined/null by default. Does C act in a similar way?

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Thanks also for the help on this one.

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Actually I believe Python it's None by default üòÆ

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Arrays and pointers differ in that you need to allocate memory to pointers. Especially for structs, the entire array will be a part of the struct

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: C does not initialize variables by default

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: They'll just be whatever bits happen to be at that part of memory at the time

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Got it. Thanks for the clarity üôÇ Just want to make sure my understanding is there. When we deal with link list. The `*n` is basically saving the address/pointer to the allocated memory we created for a node. Which is specifically said we need room to store an int (4 bytes) and a node. So when we set it to `*n` and do `n->number = 4` we are saying please store 4 in the allocated space we created for this specific node (n) at position of number. The next value known as next is nothing until we set a pointer to it which should point to the next node struct that has similar properties of number and node.

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Or does `n->number = 4` actually makes number a pointer to where 4 is stores in memory?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: The first

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: The next value is not nothing though, it can be any random value and you shouldn't use it for any checks

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You aren't changing the type of number

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: So you aren't making number a pointer

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Thank you üôÇ Just 1 final question. Sorry for this one. When you mentioned it can be any random value for next. Then how come when we want to insert a new node to the next value, we need to check for a `NULL` if it could be of any value?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: You would generally initialise to null when adding the node

Author: Yama#6436
Content: Okay now it all makes sense. Thank you for all that help even though I believe it was repeated a few times üôè

Author: SDam#7693
SDam#7693
Content: strings are different from other variable types

Author: SDam#7693
Content:
other types take a defined amount of space in memory
so when you mention a variable that is not a string in your code, the computer will immediately know how much space in memory it will have to read or write

Author: SDam#7693
Content: strings can have variable lengths, so neither you nor the computer know in advance how much space a string will occupy

Author: SDam#7693
Content: because of that, a string variable doesn't actually hold the string itself, but just the address in memory where the string starts

Author: SDam#7693
Content: a variable that holds a memory address is called a pointer

Author: SDam#7693
Content: the computer goes there and starts reading byte by byte, until it finds a byte full of 0's, which signs the end of the string

Author: SDam#7693
Content: that's called a null character

Author: SDam#7693
Content: so, since string variables don't directly hold strings, but a pointer that points to the place in memory where the actual string starts, when you compare 2 string variables using `==`, what you are actually comparing is not the strings themselves, but the value of the pointers

Author: SDam#7693
Content: you are not comparing the content of the strings, but instead you're comparing if both strings are located in the same place in memory

Author: SDam#7693
Content: so if both strings are in different places, even if the text is the same, `==` will give you `false`

Author: SDam#7693
Content: hope that helps

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: @SDam amazing explanation

Author: SDam#7693
Content: thanks!

Author: SDam#7693
Content: happy to help!

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content:
Guys, got a question regarding big-oh notation:
How do I objectively know if a value should be considered as part of the notation?
For instance, if the running time is defined by n¬≤-10, the then is considered irrelevant, so the notation is just O(n¬≤);
What if the running time is defined by, say,  2n-1, should the 2* be deemed as relevant (so O(2n)), or should the notation just be O(n)?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: yes

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: just O(n)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: have you taken calculus @Jancer Gomes ?

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: Not really (I'm taking CS-Law right now)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: wdym not really?

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: Oops, miscommunication (not a native speaker haha)

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: I haven't taken

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: ok so here goes (sorry if my explanation is not very good just bear with me)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: lets say you have O(2n) and O(n)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: as n gets bigger and bigger the 2 coefficient matters less and less because eventually, infinity times 2 is still infinity

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content:
I'm not quite sure I get it
I mean, isn't infinity times infinity also infinity?

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: The thing is, I can see how a -2 is irrelevant when we're about big values of n

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: But I can't see how doubling the n (2n) is not relevant

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: (sorry, I'm not from a math background)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: all good i have one more explanation that might work or might not im not too sure

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: think about it like this

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: what is this fraction simplified?

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: it's n, I guess

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: and so as n gets bigger and bigger that simplififed fraction gets bigger and bigger up to infinity

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: but take this for example 2n/n

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: what is that simplified?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: and as n gets bigger and bigger what happens to that fraction?

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: I guess it becomes a constant (2)

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: exactly which means compared to n, which is getting bigger and bigger up until infinity, that 2 stays where it is and never gets any bigger

Author: Jancer Gomes#0590
Content: Oh, so a good way would be dividing the value by n and see if it still changes, huh?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: sure

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: that a simple way of doing what we would call comparing the rates of growth between, for example, n^2 and n

I can't say I get it completely, but I surely feel more secure when it comes to defining the big-oh

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that means that new->next is now holding the address of the (previous) head of the list  and then `list = new` sets the address of the new node as the new head of the list

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you start with an empty list, so list = NULL

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and the first time the loop runs, you create a node for 0

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: then the 0 node's address will be stored in list

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and the 0->next will be null (because there's nothing after it)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: then, the loop runs again

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and you create the node for 1

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and then set 1->next to list (so it now points to the 0 node) and then set list to point to the 1 node

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: loop runs again and you create the 2 node.  2->next will point to 1 and list will point to 2.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you were to stop there, you'd have list->2 node->1 node->0 node->null

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: then the first 4 boxes will be the 4 bytes for the int.  and the next 8 boxes will be the 8 bytes for the pointer.

Content: and the address of the first box is the value stored in `new`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: much like in the `int *x = malloc(sizeof(int));`  the value stored in `x` is the address of a block in memory of 4 bytes  (since the size of an int is 4 bytes in the IDE)

Author: Sneks#2007
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so `float average(int length, int array[])` declare a function called `average` that takes 2 arguments, an int and an int array.  When you call it from main with `average(n, scores)`  you are passing it the 2 arguments.  The value `length` will be the value of `n` and the  `array[]` will be the `scores` array.  Remember that a function is like a block box that simply takes argument(s) and returns a value.  What those arguments are called "internally" to the function doesn't really matter to the calling function, as long as it sends the right types of variables.

Author: Akib Fahad#7124
Content:
Hello everyone. I have just started my journey in CS 50 Introduction to CS and I really love it already. I have a few question in mind about the Week 0 lecture.

1) In the sea lion program, are there two threads (one producing the sound and another the text) that are sharing the same variable mute?

2)  In Marco Polo game, does the event that is passed down as a parameter of the broadcast method that the orange puppet object invokes cause the blue puppet object to say Polo? Is this multi-threading too?

Author: FrostAxon#0459
Content: As per my knowledge, in Marco Polo game, the event is not running at the same time as the main script is running, so it's not an example of multi threading. If the two or more script are running at the same time then it can be call as multi threading

Author: Akib Fahad#7124
Content: @FrostAxon Thanks for your reply.  So the sea lion program is an example of multi-threading since there were two main programs running?

Author: FrostAxon#0459
Content: @Akib Fahad Yes! The sea lion program was an example of multi threading

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: not really, javascript doesnt support multithreading, and afaik scratch runs in the browser

Author: Akib Fahad#7124
Content: https://cs.harvard.edu/malan/scratch/threads.php

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Well yeah, guess you could call those threads but all that code will still be executed on a single cpu thread

Author: joshua.boltz#3609
Content:
Around 1:12:30 of Lecture 2: Arrays
David shows ‚ÄúH I !‚Äù in the memory squares with the null terminator.

I get confused what he means by ‚Äú8 zero bits‚Äù...because doesn‚Äôt the ‚ÄúH‚Äù take 1 bit, ‚ÄúI‚Äù take 1 bit, and ‚Äú!‚Äù take 1 bit? 1 bit because they are chars of the string, and char takes 1 bit? Thought ‚Äú\0‚Äù would take one bit as well.

Author: joshua.boltz#3609
Content: Ah he said re: null terminator, ‚Äúit just wastes one byte as all zero bits‚Äù

Author: joshua.boltz#3609
Content:
Ok next question/thought...
So, ‚ÄúH‚Äù takes up one byte for a char.
But David shows you can cast that char as an int, such as for H is the ascii  72. Int storage is 2 bytes. Interesting you can take something storing 1 byte and cast it to something taking 2 bytes.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: 72 only takes one byte of storage.  in binary  `01001000`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but you can "cast" it to an integer (which in our IDE is 4 bytes) and then it will take up `00000000 00000000 00000000 01001000`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
joshua.boltz#3609
Content: Thanks it‚Äôs been interesting to wrap my head around

Content: 72 is the ASCI number of capital H

Author: stefangutnickallen#3503
Content:
```# Prints string character by character

from cs50 import get_string

s = get_string("Input:  ")
print("Output: ", end="")
for c in s:
    print(c, end="")
print()```

What's the point of the last 'print()' function in this code? It doesn't seem to be making any difference when I run it? It's from the first lecture on python

Edit: NVM I got it. It's just to print a newline at th end because print() does that by default in python.

Author: Jayden#0466
Content:
@RomeTheWalrus For Love 0.11.1 'love.window.getPixelScale()' is replaced with 'love.window.getDPIScale()'.
To fix the error, open push.lua and replace 'love.window.getPixelScale()' with 'love.window.getDPIScale()'.

Content: hey, can anybody help me with getting the verified certificate? it's a bit pricey for me and i don't know if i'm actually skilled enough to complete the assignments properly and get the certificate. i need to make sure that i can successfully complete the course and earn the certificate before buying it. i wanted to know if the assignments are difficult and if a beginner programmer like me can actually complete them because otherwise i think you're not eligible to earn the certificate?

Author: Swervmerv#2164
Content: @Defne The assignments are challenging, but if you put in the time and effort you should be able to succeed. The class is designed so that you can start with no knowledge of programming (although, I must say it ramps up quickly!).

Author: Defne#8951
Content: @Swervmerv really? because the codes look like gibberish to me and i fear that i might just not understand programming at all :/

Author: Swervmerv#2164
Content: @Defne My advice is that you take it slowly and start with lecture 0, take as much time as you need to completely understand the assignments, and go from there. Anyone can understand if they put in the effort! It's not easy though.

Author: Defne#8951
Content: @Swervmerv okay, thanks a lot!

Content: @Defne There is also the option to buy the certificate once you are about to finish the course.

Author: ZerOv7#0812
Content:
@heaven219 here are all the steps 
This step assumes that you‚Äôve downloaded your Scratch project as a file whose name ends in .sb3. And this step also assumes that you‚Äôve signed up for a GitHub account, per the above form.

Visit this link, log in with your GitHub account, and click Authorize cs50.
Check the box indicating that you‚Äôd like to grant course staff access to your submissions, and click Join course.
Go to https://submit.cs50.io/upload/cs50/problems/2020/x/scratch.
Click ‚ÄúChoose File‚Äù and choose your .sb3 file. Click Submit.
That‚Äôs it! Once your submission uploads, you should be redirected to your submission page. Click the submission link and then the check50 link to see which requirements your project met. You are welcome to resubmit as many times as you‚Äôd like (before the deadline)!

Author: whatwhyhao#5105
Content:
Hi guys. Some questions on Week 2. Could someone explain the difference between pass by value and pass by reference in regards to arrays? What's the significance of passing by reference for arrays? e.g. could you explain the example Doug gave at the end of the Arrays video?
My understanding is that since arrays are pass by reference, the values assigned to each element within that array can not be changed by a function?

Author: Deadphyre#1594
Content: I'm a little rusty on C but the values in the arrays can be changed within the function they were created in unless you can assign variables outside of the function and make them global

Author: kamilaüåà#5238
Content: variables are passed by value, so essentially a function receives a copy of the variable to work with & the original variable doesn't change when the function is done

Author: Deadphyre#1594
Content: you could also create a blank array and have a function return whatever you want put into the array

Author: kamilaüåà#5238
Content: with arrays you are changing the value inside of the array rather than sending a copy to the function

Author: Deadphyre#1594
Content: makes sense. Again, I'm a bit rusty
